conclusion: A single-turn square wire frame is placed stationary on a horizontal surface with side length 0.2m and total resistance of 4Ω.
Half of the wire frame is in a uniform magnetic field perpendicular to the plane of the paper and directed inward.
The relationship between the magnitude of the magnetic induction intensity B and time t is B=(3 + 2t)T.
The wire frame remains stationary from t = 0 to t = 5s.
Only the right-hand half of the square (width 0.10 m, height 0.20 m) is in the field.

premise: Area in field is A = 0.10 m × 0.20 m = 2.0 × 10⁻² m².
conclusion: Magnetic flux through that half: Φ = B A.

premise: Because B varies with time, the magnitude of the induced emf is |ε| = |dΦ/dt| = A · |dB/dt| = 2.0 × 10⁻² m² × 2 T s⁻¹ = 4.0 × 10⁻² V = 0.040 V.
Induced emf is 0.040 V and resistance is 4Ω.
conclusion: Current in the frame I = |ε|/R = 0.040 V / 4 Ω = 0.010 A (10 mA).

premise: B is increasing into the page; the induced current must produce a field out of the page (to oppose the increase).
conclusion: Using the right-hand rule, that requires a counter-clockwise current in the loop when viewed from the front.

premise: Only the two vertical sides experience net horizontal forces, but the left vertical side is outside the field, so only the right vertical side (length = 0.20 m) feels a force.
conclusion: Magnitude of force F = I L B.
Magnitude of force F = 0.010 A × 0.20 m × 8 T = 1.6 × 10⁻² N = 0.016 N.

premise: Current in the right side flows upward (part of the counter-clockwise loop). By Fleming’s left-hand rule (or right-hand rule for force), with current upward and field into the page.
conclusion: The force is toward the left.

premise: The frame is said to remain stationary, so the horizontal magnetic force must be balanced by static friction of equal magnitude acting toward the right.
conclusion: At t = 2.5 s the frictional force acting on the wire frame has magnitude 0.016 N and direction to the right (opposite the magnetic force).
